title: Express Router Returns Controllers Used in the Other Router  Ask
req.body.hasOwnProperty is not a function
body:
### how to reproduce this issue? - create a project with [express-generator](https://github.com/expressjs/generator) - in `routes/index.js` add the below line: ```js router.post('/', function(req, res, next) { console.log(req.body.hasOwnProperty('asdf')); }); ``` - run the server - use postman to send a POST request with a couple of body parameters. - you'll get: ```html

req.body.hasOwnProperty is not a function


    

```
### req.body.hasOwnProperty is not a function
Why this happening? is this behaviour expected?

title: npm install express --save is giving error on windows 10
route param regexp mis-handled
body:
I want to server an API `/:natural`, the param `natural` must be a valid **natural number** (positive integer). So I wrote a route rule like this:

```js
app.get('/:natural([1-9]\\d*)', (request, response) => {
  console.log(request.params.natural)
})
```

This works with paths like `/12` or `/777`, but does not work with single digit paths like `/1` or `/3`.

It looks like caused by the asterisk character (`*`) in the regexp string. Following code works fine:

```js
app.get('/:natural([1-9]\\d{0,})', (request, response) => {
  console.log(request.params.natural)
})
```

Not sure whether this is an issue with **path-to-regexp** or express itself.

title: Discussion: MVC example
body:
In the process of replacing Jade with EJS (until Pug dependencies are sorted) I wanted to raise the discussion on how best to structure the MVC example.

Right now the in the MVC example, every "module" contains its handler and views.

I'm thinking of taking this example back to a structure like;

```
/controllers
  /user.js
  /pet.js
  /main.js
  /etc..
/views
  /pet
    /edit.html
    /show.html
/public
/db.js
/index.js
```

I was wondering if anyone has discovered any RECENT express based MVC libraries we could use as a source of inspiration?

body:
Hi Team,

I have noticed a strange behaviour in POST and PUT requests in express. I am just returning the request body to demonstrate the issue.
My node version is 6.9.2
The source code is at [https://github.com/devilgags/Node-Rest-Api](https://github.com/devilgags/Node-Rest-Api)
Firstly, if I send a POST request with body containing a key "name", then the request takes too long to process.
![post_with_name_key](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11678975/23579786/eb014d12-011a-11e7-8e7b-caf28f483801.PNG)
If I send any other json(which does not contain **name** as a key) in the body , then the request gets processed within milliseconds. 
I ran the node application with DEBUG=express:*, then I got the following logs : 
```
Listening on localhost:9001
  express:router dispatching POST /users +14s
  express:router query  : /users +2ms
  express:router expressInit  : /users +2ms
  express:router logger  : /users +1ms

POST Request Body :  { name: 'gagan' }
POST /users 200 49.709 ms - 17
```

Secondly my PUT requests are also a lot of taking time :

```

  express:router router  : /users +2ms

PUT /users 200 75.733 ms - 17
````

```js
"body-parser": "1.17.0"

title: Creating a custom renderer for a JS file
Incompatibility with datejs
body:
Not really an express bug.  Opening issue here for the sake of others wondering why their code broke.

If you install [datejs](https://github.com/abritinthebay/datejs/) it modifies the stock `Date.parse()` function to handle more date formats.  Unfortunately it now returns `null` instead of `NaN` and that breaks conditional request handling in `express.static` causing spurious 412 errors.

datejs Issue https://github.com/abritinthebay/datejs/issues/263

body:

I have a small web application set with Express + Pug

Everything looks fine, but now I want to add a plugin for improve page speed:
Critical (https://github.com/addyosmani/critical)

Basically this plugin "parses" the html + css of a page, change the css file (creating a new css file) and add INLINE in the markup some new code for css trick.

The documentation of the plugin it is very simple. but they always talking about plain HMTL files/page, NOT about markup files created by express or with languages as Pug.

So my question is:

How can try to use Critical with Pug (or any other markup language as .ejs) in Express ?
I mean: I need to take a page created in pug, parse the "final" html and css, using critical to set new inline code and then inject again into pug file.

Anyone have already face/solve this problem?

or am I going on a very complete way?

Please if anyone has tips let me know

title: parser.incoming._addHeaderLines is not a function
Settings functionality moved out of core
body:
This is based on what was discussed at the last TC meeting for a good "first step" in abstracting out parts of core than can be shared.  The changes here are rather far reaching, but they basically mean the following:

```
app.set()
app.get()
app.enable()
app.disable()
app.enabled()
app.disabled()
```

Become:

```
app.settings.set()
app.settings.get()
app.settings.enable()
app.settings.disable()
app.settings.enabled()
app.settings.disabled()
```

I think there are a bunch of points for discussion here:

1. I opted to move it all under `.settings`, mainly to resolves the weird behavior from `app.get` being multi purpose.  But it could also be done so that the methods remain the same, either via mixing them in, or explicitly calling into `.settings` as getter methods.
2. If we are already breaking the api, should we also add other changes, like removing the `enabled`/`disabled` shorthands to minimize the api surface.
3. Do people like the "setters" type functionality?  It is used to keep the features like setting `etag` but it actually setting `etag fn`.  Not sure, but it seems to me we could get rid of the whole thing but just using `etag` directly.

EDIT: standardjs compliance pending :) 
**Dont feel like doing all that busy work tonight if the whole PR might get shut down...

title: remove old deprecation warnings
body: Removes the old middleware deprecation warnings for `5.x`.

title: Call callback once on listen error
body: This is a redo of #2623.  Probably didn't need a new PR, but I took a new direction by using the `once` module, and only binding to the error event.  I think this is slightly more elegant than the previous PR.  As discussed, this is a breaking change, so can only land in a 5.x branch.

title: Replace http.STATUS_CODES with the statuses module
body:
Replaced usage of core `http.STATUS_CODES` with the list from the `statuses` module.  This was pulled out from #3213 as recommended by @dougwilson in a side conversation.  For posterity, it is known that it might be considered a "breaking" change because it changes the response text, which is why the tests were breaking.

@dougwilson I couldn't remember if you said to make the PR against 5.0 and backport it, or against 4.0 and cherry-pick it forward, I know we mentioned both ways.  Let me know if I did this the wrong way and I can fix it.

title: Moves req/res out of the repo
body:
This is VERY MUCH A WIP, but the idea is that we move the code as is out of the repo.  I did it by publishing temp packages under my personal namespace, but those repo's could be moved into @pillarjs as is, and then we would just update this.

Also, I based this off the other branch I opened today (#3213) because that included breaking integration changes.  I can easily change this to not include those if we decide not to land that PR.

title: Remove direct http dependency
Avoid deferring responses to next tick
body:
I've tested Koa.js, Express.js and Aero.js on uws and I have some feedback. If you look at how Aero.js makes use of the http module:

```
request: /
method
headers
writeHead
end
request done: /
```

The http module gets a request event, Aero.js reads method, headers, calls writeHead and then calls end. Pretty basic here, but what is important to notice is that it makes sure to be done with the request *before* the request handler returns. If we look at how Express.js (and Koa.js) works instead:

```
request: /
request done: /
method
end
request: /favicon.ico
request done: /favicon.ico
method
end
```

You see that "end" is being called *after* the request handler returned, aka it was called in the next tick. This is a big no no and blows performance and memory usage very significantly. Aero.js does 150k req/sec while Express.js and Koa.js both are limited to around 50k on my machine.

The thing is that when I benchmark with http pipelining both Koa and Express actually reduce in performance while Aero.js goes up to 530k req/sec while Koa and Express are stuck at less than 50k. I'm guessing this is because of the excessive process.nextTick / setTimeout / setImmediate / whatever usage that just clogs up under stress.

title: Perf issue against plain http server
body:
Hi folks,

I've made those tests
```js
'use strict'
var app = require('express')()
app.all('*', function(req, res) {
  res.end('Hello world')
})
app.listen(3000, () => console.log('UP http://localhost:3000'))
```
against to
```js
'use strict'
var http = require('http')
var server = http.createServer(function requestHandler(req, res) {
  res.end('Hello world')
})
server.listen(3001, () => console.log('UP http://localhost:3001'))
```

The result of a benchmark is described below
```bash
$ autocannon http://localhost:3000
Running 10s test @ http://localhost:3000
10 connections

Stat         Avg       Stdev    Max     
Latency (ms) 1.17      1.22     38      
Req/Sec      6296.4    709.15   7435    
Bytes/Sec    842.14 kB 95.87 kB 1.02 MB 

63k requests in 10s, 8.44 MB read
```

```bash
$ autocannon http://localhost:3001
Running 10s test @ http://localhost:3000
10 connections

Stat         Avg     Stdev    Max     
Latency (ms) 0.27    0.77     29      
Req/Sec      11567.2 1580.4   13535   
Bytes/Sec    1.28 MB 178.4 kB 1.51 MB 

116k requests in 10s, 12.84 MB read
```

I know I'm comparing a plain http web server with an web framework and I know the difference, but there's a 0.5 factor, in a plain example without any other middleware.

NB: maybe the problem is here https://github.com/expressjs/express/blob/master/lib/middleware/init.js#L28

According to this giude (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/The_performance_hazards_of__%5B%5BPrototype%5D%5D_mutation), this operation slows down "the other code".

title: render in router with view header.mustache as parameter of readfilesync(index.html)
Add Readme guidelines
body:
Per https://github.com/expressjs/discussions/issues/33 and https://github.com/expressjs/discussions/issues/51 this PR adds a new `README-guidelines.md` file with the content of the previously-reviewed file from the expressjs.com wiki.  In this file, I added the "Contributing" section from https://github.com/mysqljs/mysql#contributing as suggested by @dougwilson 

The README guidelines refers to a new [README template](https://github.com/expressjs/express/wiki/README-template) in the wiki in this repo.

I made a few small related changes:
- Added a reference to StandardJS to the `Collaborator-Guide.md` since the TC adopted this as our style, but it was not mentioned anywhere.
- Edited `Contributing.md` to remove text carried over from Node.js project, and make it more specific to Express.js project, plus some minor wording edits.

@expressjs/express-tc

title: examples: fix pbkdf2 invocation
body:
Calling `crypto.pbkdf2()` without a digest has been deprecated in Node and is scheduled to be broken in Node 8.

Fix this by actually passing a digest.

ref: https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/11305

**Note**: `npm test` still fails with Node master for me, but I’m on it :S

title: Add UWS_HTTP environment variable
body:
By setting the UWS_HTTP environment variable to truthy one can now
experiment with uws as the low level HTTP library (as opposed to
core Node.js HTTP)

#3205 

This is not very optimal but should be enough to allow experimentation

title: Small changes needed for uws compatibility
body:
Hi,

I just managed to get Express working ontop of uws (enough to get a benchmark running at least) and there are some small changes needed to allow this:

In response.js and in request.js files there are http.ServerResponse.prototype and http.IncomingMessage.prototype references which are later attached to the req and res objects in the initializer middleware -> these needs to change to require('uws').http.getResponsePrototype() and require('uws').http.getRequestPrototype() accordingly.

My thinking is it might be best to have some kind of option or environment variable or something like that to easily swap between the two different sets of prototypes and maybe also use that option in app.listen() so that one can easily swap the backend? I don't know how you feel about adding this to Express but since the changes are very small and contained I think it should be okay?

I haven't made any PR yet because I want to see how you want it to be done first.

title: ExpressJS using very out-of-date version of path-to-regexp
body:
In expressjs package.json the version of "path-to-regexp" listed in dependencies is "0.1.7".
This is considerably out-of-date with the the version of "path-to-regexp" in "pillarjs" which is "1.7.0".

Pulling the current "pillarjs" version of "path-to-regexp" into expressjs by upping the version number to
"1.7.0" in expressjs's package.json causes at least one of the expressjs tests to fail (no surprise I guess).

```
node_modules/path-to-regexp/index.js:394
  return attachKeys(new RegExp('^' + route, flags(options)), keys)
                    ^

SyntaxError: Invalid regular expression: /^\/files\/((?:*))(?:\/(?=$))?$/: Nothing to repeat
    at RegExp (native)
```

Is there any reason why expressjs is still using the "0.1.7" version of "path-to-regexp" and/or can this
out-of-date version issue be remedied?

Thanks for comments/help, Justin Johansson

title: Weird code for defining `get` method
express.static - add support for cache-control: immutable
body:
On static content with versioned URLs, add a flag to options on express.static that generates a cache-control header with immutable, e.g.:
`Cache-Control: max-age=365000000, immutable`
This reduces unnecessary requests in supporting clients.

This is supported by Firefox 49 and used by Facebook:
https://hacks.mozilla.org/2017/01/using-immutable-caching-to-speed-up-the-web/
https://bitsup.blogspot.co.uk/2016/05/cache-control-immutable.html

Supported in Chrome 54
https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=611416

Webkit support seems to be added:
https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=167497

My question is: Do I have to run those middlewares separately on the main router (Express app) and all separate routers or just once on main app is enough?

title: Support "Accept" header content preference in error page example
body:
I experienced this confusion when testing the 404 example with Backbone.js (which internally uses jquery).  

When Backbone calls `$.getJSON`, the `Accept` header is set to `application/json, text/javascript, */*; q=0.01`.  However, an HTML response is returned rather than a JSON response.

To prevent confusion for others it would be preferable to use the array argument type, which will  select the best match for media type, properly returning a JSON response if `application/json` is first in the "Accept" request-header list.

title: misbehavior for query arrays
body:
When i try run request like this:
```
site.com/?gf[1]=1,2,3&gf[22]=67,68
```
i get:
```js
req.query.gf = {"1" : "1,2,3",  "22" : "67,68"}
```
I think,this is right.
But, if i run `site/?gf[1]=1,2,3` (only one gf section), i get Array, not object:
```js
req.query.gf = ["1,2,3"]
```
It may be something like `{"1" : "1,2,3"}` ?

title: Using let instead of var to declare the counter in the for loop.
body: Using let instead of var to declare the counter in the for loop in order to keep the counter local to the loop.

title: res.send(body, encoding)
body:
Feature request:

as res.send(body, status) is slowly deprecated, shouldn't a useful encoding optional 2nd argument be allowed in a next version? ('utf8' by default)

It doesn't change in v5:
https://github.com/expressjs/express/blob/5.0/lib/response.js#L155

encoding is hardcoded, and set to undefined (I don't know why)

the goal is to allow to do:

```
res.write(data, 'binary');
res.end(null, 'binary');
```
with just `res.send(data, 'binary')`

title: Release 4.15
body:
This is a tracking issue for release 4.15.

**Please keep feature requests in their own issues**

If you want to make a comment on a particular change, please make the comment in the "Files changed" tab so comments are not lost during a rebase.

List of changes for release:
- [x] Add debug message when loading view engine #3158
- [x] Backport changes in `router@1.3.0`
  - [x] Add `next("router")` to exit from router #2241 #2371 
  - [x] Fix case where `router.use` skipped requests routes did not #3037
  - [x] Skip routing when `req.url` is not set
  - [x] Use `%o` in path debug to tell types apart
  - [x] lint: consolidate layer match failure path
  - [x] lint: remove unreachable code
  - [x] perf: add fast match path for `*` route
- [x] Improve `req.ips` performance #2723
- [x] Remove usage of `res._headers` private field #3174
- [x] Support Node.js 7.x
- [x] Upgrade `debug` module to 2.6.1
- [x] Upgrade `etag` module to 1.8.0 to bring in OOB FIPS compliance
- [x] Upgrade `finalhandler` module to 1.0.0 to bring in full HTML documents and security headers
- [x] Upgrade `fresh` module to 0.5.0 to bring in bug fixes and perf improvements
- [x] Upgrade `qs` module to 6.3.1 to bring in minor bug fixes
- [x] Upgrade `send` module to 0.15.0 to bring in precondition checks
- [x] Upgrade `serve-static` module to 1.12.0
- [x] Use `Object.create` to setup request & response prototypes
- [x] Use `setprototypeof` module to replace `__proto__` setting #3164 #3103 #2613 #1967
- [x] Use `statuses` instead of `http` module for status messages #3215

**Testing this release**

If you want to try out this release, you can install it with the following commands:

``` bash
$ npm cache clean express
$ npm install expressjs/express#4.15
```

Owners/collaborators: please do not merge this PR :)

title: Caching issues
body:
Hi,
  I am using ``expressjs`` in my ``nodejs`` application. We have internationalization(supporting multiple languages) in our application. For this internationalization to achieve i used `i18next` with ``mongodb`` backend. when ever i update translations i used to reload the translations. It is working fine in my local machine. But in Linux environment it is misbehaving. like first time page refresh it is giving me correct name,but from next refresh of same page onwards giving me old data. In browser console also updated data only printing. So i approached `i18next` team to look into it. After debugging, they told that it might be a some cache issue related to express js . So i am posting here my problem. Kindly suggest me. i have been stagnated by this issue since 10 days.
i am using ``expressjs 4.12.4`` version.

Thanks in Advance.

The query I'm trying to execute is: 
**localhost:3000/ads?subcategory=Health%20%26%20Beauty**
So I would expect req.query.subcategory to be "Health & Beauty" instead subcategory is "Health "
and req.query[" Beauty"] is "". Is this supposed to happen? It seems the url is being decoded before it splits on ampersands. Is this a problem with some other url parsing package I am using?

I'm not sure where this is supposed to be posted as an issue.

I did that according [doc](https://expressjs.com/en/api.html#res.redirect)
```

});
```

title: Why is `new Layer(path...)` used inside `Router` instead of `Layer(path...)`
ETag header does not change with header mutation
body:
I was reading parts of the [IETF RFC7826](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7826#section-16.1.3) and noticed that a strong validator is technically one that changes whenever the entity body and/or entity headers change. I spun up a simple express app to see how this works. I used `app.set('etag', 'strong')` to ensure express was setting strong ETag headers on responses (that don't come form `express.static(..)` as apparently that's a whole different thing). I found that express's ETag headers do not change when the actual headers change though. A quick visual of this can be seen below, as I add another header to a response yet the ETag stays identical.

![express-etag](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9669289/21661136/a2cfc710-d2a0-11e6-9054-95a3264ab20c.png)

I quickly dug into the express source to see why this was, and from what I can tell this is happening because in the [`lib/response.js#L184`](https://github.com/expressjs/express/blob/master/lib/response.js#L184) where we actually generate the ETag, we're only passing in `chunk`, which seems to be equal to only the body content. It might make sense, for ETags to be "strong", to send in both the chunk (body) and some string representation of the headers at the time, so the ETag can be generated based off of both.

Willing to take a stab at this if express commiters agree it should be done.

title: Serve static files based on changing config file at runtime
body: Is it possible to make a get/post request that forces the server to require the new version number and changes what static files are served?  This is for a live versioning/feature toggling aspect of my application.  Or is there a better more standard way of doing feature toggling.
